boat.construction_details: A mix of planking material on english oak frames, iron ballast keel, plywood decks
boat.full_description:
Speranza was built in 1902 by Liver & Wilding and is the first boat to appear on Lloyds Register as a Liver & Wilding built boat after their purchase of the J Gibson and Sons yard in Fleetwood. Beginning with Rev J. P. Way, DD, headmaster of the Rossal School, Speranza changed hands frequently, until arriving in Lymington in 1939.
In mid June 1945, she was moored in the upper Thames when she was purchased for £800 by Hans De Meiss-Teuffen, a double agent in the early days of the war. As a Swiss national, he was able to obtain a sailing permit the day after VJ day, and Speranza was the first yacht to leave England after the war.
After a sailing to Casablanca by way of Portugual and Gibraltar, Speranza left for New London, Connecticut, setting a record at the time for fastest northern route crossing solo, at 58 days. She was on display at the Mystic Seaport Museum for several years after her arrival, and has remained in the area since.  
She is currently undergoing restoration
